Cosine similarity it only looks at their direction and tells us how much two things are pointing in the same direction, irrespective of there distance from each other. In simple words, it is similar to asking, “Do these two people have the same idea, even if they say it differently?” It’s widely used in AI, machine learning, text analysis, and recommendation systems, especially when comparing two texts or items. How is It Used? Search engines: Find documents similar to your query Recommendation systems: Recommend similar movies, books, or products Chatbots: Understand if user messages are similar to known questions Basic Understanding Example: Let’s say we have two sentences: A: “I love ice cream.” B: “I enjoy ice cream.” These are different sentences, but they mean almost the same thing. Cosine similarity helps the computer understand that these two are very close in meaning almost like how your brain naturally understands it. Cosine similarity turns angle into a score between -1 and 1, If the Output: +1 → Vectors are p

ointing in the same direction means very similar 0 → Vectors are perpendicular and has no similarity. -1 → Vectors are pointing in opposite direction and are completely dissimilar. Cosine Similarity Formula: cos(Θ)= A.B ÷||A||×||B|| Let us know, how it works; Here A.B is the dot product (it is a way to combine them into a single number of two vectors are combined into a single number). Example, consider these vectors; Vector A= [a1, a2, an] and Vector B= [b1, b2, bn] then; A. B= a1*b1+ a2*b2+…+ an*bn ||A|| and ||B|| are the length (Euclidean norm) of a vector from the distance of origin to the point represented by the vector. Example, if a vector A = [a1, a2, a3, …an] then: ||A|| = √a12+a22…+an2 Example, let us say; A = [3,2,0,5] Then the magnitude is: ||A|| = √32+22+02+52 √38 = 6.16(Approx) This value tells us the "length" of the arrow from the origin [0, 0, 0, 0] to [3, 2, 0, 5].  Similarity: Movie Recommendation Using Cosine Similarity Suppose you are building a movie recommendation system. Two users have rated the same 5 movies. We want to check how similar their tastes are using cosine similarity. Step1: Covert these ratings into vectors: User 1= [5,4,0,5,3] and User 2= [4,5,0,4,2] Step 2: Dot product (A.B) = (5x4) + (4×5) + (0×0) + (5×4) + (3×2) = 20 + 20 + 0 + 20 + 6 = 66 Step 3: Magnitude of A =√(5² + 4² + 0² + 5² + 3²) = √(25 + 16 + 0 + 25 + 9 = √75 ≈ 8.66 Step 4: Magnitude of B = √(4² + 5² + 0² + 4² + 2²) = √(16 + 25 + 0 + 16 + 4) = √61 ≈ 7.81 Step 5: Cosine Similarity = 66 / (8.66 × 7.81) = 66 / 67.62 ≈ 0.976 Now you can conclude that cosine similarity value close to 1 means that User 1 and User 2 have very similar movie preferences and we can recommend movies to one user based on the other’s choices. Why can’t we use Euclidean Distance? Week1 1.2 Cover cosine similarity, dense vs sparse retrieval • Cosine similarity is a way to find out how similar two things are when we are comparing texts or data. Cosine similarity it only looks at their direction and tells us how much two things are pointing in the same direction, irrespective of there distance from each other. • In simple words, it is similar to asking, “Do these two people have the same idea, even if they say it differently?” • It’s widely used in AI, machine learning, text analysis, and recommendation systems, especially when comparing two texts or items. How is It Used? • Search engines: Find documents similar to your query • Recommendation systems: Recommend similar movies, books, or products • Chatbots: Understand if user messages are similar to known questions Basic Understanding Example: Let’s say we have two sentences: A: “I love ice cream.” B: “I enjoy ice cream.” These are different sentences, but they mean almost the same thing. Cosine similarity helps the computer understand that these two are very close in meaning almost like how your brain naturally understands it.  Vectors are pointing in the same direction means very similar • 0 → Vectors are perpendicular and has no similarity. • -1 → Vectors are pointing in opposite direction and are completely dissimilar. If Cosine similarity turns angle into a score between -1 and 1, If the Output: • +1 → Vectors are pointing in the same direction means very similar • 0 → Vectors are perpendicular and has no similarity. • -1 → Vectors are pointing in opposite direction and are completely dissimilar. Cosine Similarity Formula: cos(Θ)= A.B ÷||A||×||B|| Let us know, how it works; • Here A.B is the dot product (it is a way to combine them into a single number of two vectors are combined into a single number). Example, consider these vectors; Vector A= [a1, a2, an] and Vector B= [b1, b2, bn] then; A. B= a1*b1+ a2*b2+…+ an*bn • ||A|| and ||B|| are the length (Euclidean norm) of a vector from the distance of origin to the point represented by the vector. Example, if a vector A = [a1, a2, a3, …an] then: ||A|| = √a12+a22…+an2 Example, let us say; A = [3,2,0,5] Then the magnitude is: ||A|| = √32+22+02+52 √38 = 6.16(Approx) This value tells us the "length" of the arrow from the origin [0, 0, 0, 0] to [3, 2, 0, 5].
---
 Real-Life Example of Cosine Similarity: Movie Recommendation Using Cosine Similarity Suppose you are building a movie recommendation system. Two users have rated the same 5 movies. We want to check how similar their tastes are using cosine similarity. Movie User 1 Ratings User 2 Ratings KGF 5 4 Titanic 4 5 Avatar 0 0 Rowdy Rathore 5 4 Joker 3 2 Step1: Covert these ratings into vectors: User 1= [5,4,0,5,3] and User 2= [4,5,0,4,2] Step 2: Dot product (A.B) = (5x4) + (4×5) + (0×0) + (5×4) + (3×2) = 20 + 20 + 0 + 20 + 6 = 66 Step 3: Magnitude of A =√(5² + 4² + 0² + 5² + 3²) = √(25 + 16 + 0 + 25 + 9 = √75 ≈ 8.66 Step 4: Magnitude of B = √(4² + 5² + 0² + 4² + 2²) = √(16 + 25 + 0 + 16 + 4) = √61 ≈ 7.81 Step 5: Cosine Similarity = 66 / (8.66 × 7.81) = 66 / 67.62 ≈ 0.976 Now you can conclude that cosine similarity value close to 1 means that User 1 and User 2 have very similar movie preferences and we can recommend movies to one user based on the other’s choices. Why can’t we use Euclidean Distance? Week 1 Research: What is a vector embedding? Why is it used in AI search? A vector embedding is a way to turn words or sentences into numbers so that a computer can understand their meaning, it contributes in finding similar things. Vector embedding are numerical representations of texts, images or other forms of data where each object is transformed into a list of numbers called a vector in a multi-dimensional space, It just means there are many features being tracked at once, each dimension represents specific feature of the data like its meaning, emotion, context. Vectors are nothing but list of numbers, and we need a way to match meanings, not just words, that’s what embeddings do. Let us assume computers as human and the scenario while searching will be, the sentences that are close in terms of meaning, the computer concludes that they’re probably talking about the same thing. Example: Let us suppose Dog’s vector [0.23, 0.99, -0.12, ..., 0.77] and Cat’s vector [0.24, 0.98, -0.11, ..., 0.76], these numbers are called embeddings. Each value denotes a feature or characteristic like tail size, color, etc. We teach computers to convert words into numbers in such a way that similar

How is It Used? • Search engines: Find documents similar to your query • Recommendation systems: Recommend similar movies, books, or products • Chatbots: Understand if user messages are similar to known questions Basic Understanding Example: Let’s say we have two sentences: A: “I love ice cream.” B: “I enjoy ice cream.” These are different sentences, but they mean almost the same thing. Cosine similarity helps the computer understand that these two are very close in meaning almost like how your brain naturally understands it. Cosine similarity turns angle into a score between -1 and 1, If the Output: • +1 →

Week 1 Research: What is a vector embedding? Why is it used in AI search? A vector embedding is a way to turn words or sentences into numbers so that a computer can understand their meaning, it contributes in finding similar things. Vector embedding are numerical representations of texts, images or other forms of data where each object is transformed into a list of numbers called a vector in a multi-dimensional space, It just means there are many features being tracked at once, each dimension represents specific feature of the data like its meaning, emotion, context. Vectors are nothing but list of numbers, and we need a way to match meanings, not just words, that’s what embeddings do. Let us assume computers as human and the scenario while searching will be, the sentences that are close in terms of meaning, the computer concludes that they’re probably talking about the same thing. Example: Let us suppose Dog’s vector [0.23, 0.99, -0.12, ..., 0.77] and Cat’s vector [0.24, 0.98, -0.11, ..., 0.76], these numbers are called embeddings. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): Developed by Facebook AI, RAG is used for QA and generative tasks. Use case: Chatbots, virtual assistants, document QA, LLMs with memory, Users ask long or fuzzy questions Example: User Query: “How can I treat a headache naturally?” Sparse Retrieval (BM25): Finds 100 documents with the words “headache”, “treat”, etc Dense Embeddings: Encodes the query and the 100 docs and then ranks them using semantic similarity(dense). Context:
Week 1 Research: What is a vector embedding? Why is it used in AI search? A vector embedding is a way to turn words or sentences into numbers so that a computer can understand their meaning, it contributes in finding similar things. Vector embedding are numerical representations of texts, images or other forms of data where each object is transformed into a list of numbers called a vector in a multi-dimensional space, It just means there are many features being tracked at once, each dimension represents specific feature of the data like its meaning, emotion, context. Vectors are nothing but list of numbers, and we need a way to match meanings, not just words, that’s what embeddings do. Let us assume computers as human and the scenario while searching will be, the sentences that are close in terms of meaning, the computer concludes that they’re probably talking about the same thing. Example: Let us suppose Dog’s vector [0.23, 0.99, -0.12, ..., 0.77] and Cat’s vector [0.24, 0.98, -0.11, ..., 0.76], these numbers are called embeddings. Each value denotes a feature or characteristic like tail size, color, etc. We teach computers to convert words into numbers in such a way that similar
words get similar numbers. As you can observe they are closed in dimensional space i.e. in computer, which means they are semantically similar such that even if the values are different the meaning can be same. Embeddings capture the intent and meaning, not just the words and they convert data into numbers so that computers can understand, compare, and work with them based on meaning, not exact words. It is used in AI as each vector carries semantic meaning of the input, which helps in searching through meaning unlike previously used methods which uses keyword matching which may fail when different words mean the same. The vectors hold properties/ characteristics/features of the object in a form such that it is easily understandable to machine learning models for faster outputs. Example: Bag 1 has its features red colored, medium sized, costs $50, and is from brand Nike i.e. Bag A - [Red, Medium, ₹500, Nike] then computer will store and fetch it like Bag A - [0.8, 0.6, 0.7, 0.9] and similarly assume Bag B - [0.7, 0.6, 0.9, 0.3]. We can now assume that they are closely related. Vector embeddings help AI by turning meaning into numbers, so it can compare, understand what we meant, ev
match. It also considers meanings and intent, not just words. Example: Query - “How to reduce body heat?” It finds matches with “Home remedies for fever”, as you can see the result is based on semantic, not word-to-word. Example: Imagine describing a person in a sentence: “He is tall, athletic, and friendly.” Now if we write these traits as vectors i.e. [0.8, 0.9, 0.7], Each number represents how strongly that trait appears that is tallness, athleticism, friendliness. This is a dense vector all positions are filled with meaningful values. Even if the two sentences share no exact words, their dense vector embeddings are close, because they mean the same thing. Hybrid Retrieval is a technique that combines both, Sparse retrieval based on keyword matching and Dense retrieval based on semantic similarity to leverage the strengths of both to create a more robust, accurate and efficient search system. Improves accuracy by getting more relevant results by combining precision(sparse) and recall(dense). Tools & Frameworks That Use Hybrid Retrieval; 1. ColBERTv2: ColBERT stands for "Contextualized Late Interaction over BERT", It allows dense vectors for fine-grained token-level matching, bu

Vector embedding are numerical representations of texts, images or other forms of data where each object is transformed into a list of numbers called a vector in a multi-dimensional space, It just means there are many features being tracked at once, each dimension represents specific feature of the data like its meaning, emotion, context. Vectors are nothing but list of numbers, and we need a way to match meanings, not just words, that’s what embeddings do. Let us assume computers as human and the scenario while searching will be, the sentences that are close in terms of meaning, the computer concludes that they’re probably talking about the same thing. Example: Let us suppose Dog’s vector [0.23, 0.99, -0.12, ..., 0.77] and Cat’s vector [0.24, 0.98, -0.11, ..., 0.76], these numbers are called embeddings. Each value denotes a feature or characteristic like tail size, color, etc. We teach computers to convert words into numbers in such a way that similar

Week 1 1.3 Explore tools to generate embeddings: OpenAI, HuggingFace, sentence-transformers Embeddings are numerical vectors representing texts or images which holds their meaning, so that similar content has similar vectors and are used in search engines, recommendation systems, semantic similarities, etc. OpenAI Embeddings: OpenAI provides embedding models like text-embedding-ada-002, which are fast, cheap, and accurate for text similarity, search, clustering, etc.OpenAI generates dense vector embeddings from texts. When we send a prompt in text format to the API called the Application Program Interface are set of rules that allow different software applications to communicate with each other, and then it returns a high dimensional vector (large list of number) and for text-embedding-ada-002 it is 1536 dimensions, it uses its trained AI model to convert our sentence into a list of numbers. Use cases: Semantic Search: that is searching based on meanings instead of only looking for texts. Uses cosine similarity to find the nearest document vectors. Document Clustering: where documents are taken and converted into embedding vectors, and then are grouped with similar vectors using al

words get similar numbers. As you can observe they are closed in dimensional space i.e. in computer, which means they are semantically similar such that even if the values are different the meaning can be same. Embeddings capture the intent and meaning, not just the words and they convert data into numbers so that computers can understand, compare, and work with them based on meaning, not exact words. It is used in AI as each vector carries semantic meaning of the input, which helps in searching through meaning unlike previously used methods which uses keyword matching which may fail when different words mean the same. The vectors hold properties/ characteristics/features of the object in a form such that it is easily understandable to machine learning models for faster outputs. Example: Bag 1 has its features red colored, medium sized, costs $50, and is from brand Nike i.e. Bag A - [Red, Medium, ₹500, Nike] then computer will store and fetch it like Bag A - [0.8, 0.6, 0.7, 0.9] and similarly assume Bag B - [0.7, 0.6, 0.9, 0.3]. We can now assume that they are closely related. Vector embeddings help AI by turning meaning into numbers, so it can compare, understand what we meant, ev

Context:
Week1 1.2 Cover cosine similarity, dense vs sparse retrieval • Cosine similarity is a way to find out how similar two things are when we are comparing texts or data. Cosine similarity it only looks at their direction and tells us how much two things are pointing in the same direction, irrespective of there distance from each other. • In simple words, it is similar to asking, “Do these two people have the same idea, even if they say it differently?” • It’s widely used in AI, machine learning, text analysis, and recommendation systems, especially when comparing two texts or items. How is It Used? • Search engines: Find documents similar to your query • Recommendation systems: Recommend similar movies, books, or products • Chatbots: Understand if user messages are similar to known questions Basic Understanding Example: Let’s say we have two sentences: A: “I love ice cream.” B: “I enjoy ice cream.” These are different sentences, but they mean almost the same thing. Cosine similarity helps the computer understand that these two are very close in meaning almost like how your brain naturally understands it. Cosine similarity turns angle into a score between -1 and 1, If the Output: • +1 →

Cosine similarity it only looks at their direction and tells us how much two things are pointing in the same direction, irrespective of there distance from each other. In simple words, it is similar to asking, “Do these two people have the same idea, even if they say it differently?” It’s widely used in AI, machine learning, text analysis, and recommendation systems, especially when comparing two texts or items. How is It Used? Search engines: Find documents similar to your query Recommendation systems: Recommend similar movies, books, or products Chatbots: Understand if user messages are similar to known questions Basic Understanding Example: Let’s say we have two sentences: A: “I love ice cream.” B: “I enjoy ice cream.” These are different sentences, but they mean almost the same thing. Cosine similarity helps the computer understand that these two are very close in meaning almost like how your brain naturally understands it. Cosine similarity turns angle into a score between -1 and 1, If the Output: +1 → Vectors are p
Vectors are pointing in the same direction means very similar • 0 → Vectors are perpendicular and has no similarity. • -1 → Vectors are pointing in opposite direction and are completely dissimilar. If Cosine similarity turns angle into a score between -1 and 1, If the Output: • +1 → Vectors are pointing in the same direction means very similar • 0 → Vectors are perpendicular and has no similarity. • -1 → Vectors are pointing in opposite direction and are completely dissimilar. Cosine Similarity Formula: cos(Θ)= A.B ÷||A||×||B|| Let us know, how it works; • Here A.B is the dot product (it is a way to combine them into a single number of two vectors are combined into a single number). Example, consider these vectors; Vector A= [a1, a2, an] and Vector B= [b1, b2, bn] then; A. B= a1*b1+ a2*b2+…+ an*bn • ||A|| and ||B|| are the length (Euclidean norm) of a vector from the distance of origin to the point represented by the vector. Example, if a vector A = [a1, a2, a3, …an] then: ||A|| = √a12+a22…+an2 Example, let us say; A = [3,2,0,5] Then the magnitude is: ||A|| = √32+22+02+52 √38 = 6.16(Approx) This value tells us the "length" of the arrow from the origin [0, 0, 0, 0] to [3, 2, 0, 5].

Context:
cess of finding relevant documents or information from a large collection of data when a user provides a query and similarly in the context of deep learning and neural search the terms dense retrieval and sparse retrieval refer to two different approaches for retrieving relevant data based on a user’s query. Sparse Retrieval: also known as sparse neural search, is an approach to information retrieval that uses sparse vector (A sparse vector is a list of numbers where most of the values are zero) representations of queries and documents. Sparse retrieval represents queries and documents as high-dimensional vectors (this list has a lot of numbers hundreds, thousands, or even millions of dimensions) where most values are zero. It uses traditional IR techniques like BM25. Characteristics of sparse retrieval: Search on the basis of keywords: it works by matching exact words instead of searching through meaning between the query and the document, like if your query contains the word “banana”, it will only retrieve documents that also contain the term “banana”. No Deep learning is required: Sparse methods like BM25 are mathematical formulas they don’t need a trained neural network which m
val vs Dense Retrieval To get started with these we must first understand what is Information Retrieval (IR), it is the process of finding relevant documents or information from a large collection of data when a user provides a query and similarly in the context of deep learning and neural search the terms dense retrieval and sparse retrieval refer to two different approaches for retrieving relevant data based on a user’s query. Sparse Retrieval: also known as sparse neural search, is an approach to information retrieval that uses sparse vector (A sparse vector is a list of numbers where most of the values are zero) representations of queries and documents. Sparse retrieval represents queries and documents as high-dimensional vectors (this list has a lot of numbers hundreds, thousands, or even millions of dimensions) where most values are zero. It uses traditional IR techniques like BM25. Characteristics of sparse retrieval: 1. Search on the basis of keywords: it works by matching exact words instead of searching through meaning between the query and the document, like if your query contains the word “banana”, it will only retrieve documents that also contain the term “banana”. 2.
akes them easy to use and fast. Fast, Interpretable, and Effective for Exact Match: because it uses indexing making it ideal for search engines. Sparse retrieval is not limited to text data. Extensions of sparse retrieval approaches to the vision-language domain enable the retrieval of relevant content across different models such as finding images based on text queries. Example: You walk into a supermarket with 10,000 shelves, and each shelf has a different item rice, toothpaste, laptop, pen, etc. You go in just to buy 3 things: milk, bread, and butter; Shelf 1 (rice): 0 Shelf 2 (soap): 0 Shelf 3 (milk): 1 Shelf 4 (bread): 1 Shelf 5 (butter): 1 Shelf 6 (shampoo): 0 ……. Shelf 10,000 (watch): 0 This is your shopping vector and you can see 3 positions have 1s I mean the items you have picked this is called a sparse vector because most of the values are zeros, and only a few are non-zero. Sparse retrieval represents queries and documents as high-dimensional vectors (this list has a lot of numbers hundreds, thousands, or even millions of dimensions) where most values are zero. It uses traditional IR techniques like BM25. Characteristics of sparse retrieval: Search on the basis of keywords: it works by matching exact words instead of searching through meaning between the query and the document, like if your query contains the word “banana”, it will only retrieve documents that also contain the term “banana”. Cosine similarity helps the computer understand that these two are very close in meaning almost like how your brain naturally understands it. Vectors are pointing in the same direction means very similar • 0 → Vectors are perpendicular and has no similarity. • -1 → Vectors are pointing in opposite direction and are completely dissimilar. If Cosine similarity turns angle into a score between -1 and 1, If the Output: • +1 → Vectors are pointing in the same direction means very similar • 0 → Vectors are perpendicular and has no similarity. • -1 → Vectors are pointing in opposite direction and are completely dissimilar. Cosine Similarity Formula: cos(Θ)= A.B ÷||A||×||B|| Let us know, how it works; • Here A.B is the dot product (it is a way to combine them into a single number of two vectors are combined into a single number). Example, consider these vectors; Vector A= [a1, a2, an] and Vector B= [b1, b2, bn] then; A. B= a1*b1+ a2*b2+…+ an*bn • ||A|| and ||B|| are the length (Euclidean norm) of a vector from the distance of origin to the point represented by the vector. Example, if a vector A = [a1, a2, a3, …an] then: ||A|| = √a12+a22…+an2 Example, let us say; A = [3,2,0,5] Then the magnitude is: ||A|| = √32+22+02+52 √38 = 6.16(Approx) This value tells us the "length" of the arrow from the origin [0, 0, 0, 0] to [3, 2, 0, 5].

Through this observation Oersted showed that electricity and magnetism were related phenomena. His research later created technologies such as the radio, television and fiber optics. The unit of magnetic field strength is named the oersted in his honor. Week1 1.2 Cover cosine similarity, dense vs sparse retrieval • Cosine similarity is a way to find out how similar two things are when we are comparing texts or data. Cosine similarity it only looks at their direction and tells us how much two things are pointing in the same direction, irrespective of there distance from each other. • In simple words, it is similar to asking, “Do these two people have the same idea, even if they say it differently?” • It’s widely used in AI, machine learning, text analysis, and recommendation systems, especially when comparing two texts or items. How is It Used? • Search engines: Find documents similar to your query • Recommendation systems: Recommend similar movies, books, or products • Chatbots: Understand if user messages are similar to known questions Basic Understanding Example: Let’s say we have two sentences: A: “I love ice cream.” B: “I enjoy ice cream.” These are different sentences, but they mean almost the same thing. Cosine similarity helps the computer understand that these two are very close in meaning almost like how your brain naturally understands it. How is It Used? Search engines: Find documents similar to your query Recommendation systems: Recommend similar movies, books, or products Chatbots: Understand if user messages are similar to known questions Basic Understanding Example: Let’s say we have two sentences: A: “I love ice cream.” B: “I enjoy ice cream.” These are different sentences, but they mean almost the same thing. Vectors are pointing in the same direction means very similar • 0 → Vectors are perpendicular and has no similarity. • -1 → Vectors are pointing in opposite direction and are completely dissimilar. If Cosine similarity turns angle into a score between -1 and 1, If the Output: • +1 → Vectors are pointing in the same direction means very similar • 0 → Vectors are perpendicular and has no similarity. • -1 → Vectors are pointing in opposite direction and are completely dissimilar. Cosine Similarity Formula: cos(Θ)= A.B ÷||A||×||B|| Let us know, how it works; • Here A.B is the dot product (it is a way to combine them into a single number of two vectors are combined into a single number). Example, consider these vectors; Vector A= [a1, a2, an] and Vector B= [b1, b2, bn] then; A. B= a1*b1+ a2*b2+…+ an*bn • ||A|| and ||B|| are the length (Euclidean norm) of a vector from the distance of origin to the point represented by the vector. Example, if a vector A = [a1, a2, a3, …an] then: ||A|| = √a12+a22…+an2 Example, let us say; A = [3,2,0,5] Then the magnitude is: ||A|| = √32+22+02+52 √38 = 6.16(Approx) This value tells us the "length" of the arrow from the origin [0, 0, 0, 0] to [3, 2, 0, 5].

Example, consider these vectors; Vector A= [a1, a2, an] and Vector B= [b1, b2, bn] then; A. B= a1*b1+ a2*b2+…+ an*bn • ||A|| and ||B|| are the length (Euclidean norm) of a vector from the distance of origin to the point represented by the vector. Example, if a vector A = [a1, a2, a3, …an] then: ||A|| = √a12+a22…+an2 Example, let us say; A = [3,2,0,5] Then the magnitude is: ||A|| = √32+22+02+52 √38 = 6.16(Approx) This value tells us the "length" of the arrow from the origin [0, 0, 0, 0] to [3, 2, 0, 5].

[flocard_faq.json] A non-procedural language is a type of programming language where the user specifies what the program should accomplish without detailing how to achieve it, allowing the underlying system to determine the execution process.
Characteristics of Non-Procedural Languages
Declarative Approach: Non-procedural languages, also known as declarative languages, focus on defining the desired outcomes rather than the specific steps to reach those outcomes. This approach allows for more concise and expressive code 
2
.
Function Development: These languages enable the creation of complex functions from simpler, existing functions. This means that coding is often shorthand for specifying relationships, constraints, or operations 
2
.
Simplicity: The semantics of non-procedural languages tend to be simpler compared to procedural languages. This simplicity can lead to improved readability and easier maintenance of code 
2
.
Automatic Optimization: The underlying systems can often optimize execution automatically, which helps in achieving better performance without requiring manual optimization by the developer 
1
.


4 Sources
Examples of Non-Procedural Languages
SQL (Structured Query Language): Used for managing and querying relational databases, SQL allows users to request data without needing to specify the exact retrieval method.
LISP: A language primarily used in artificial intelligence, known for its symbolic expression capabilities and functional programming features.
PROLOG: A logic programming language that emphasizes the use of rules and facts to perform logical inference 
2
.


2 Sources
Advantages of Non-Procedural Languages
Higher Productivity: Since these languages allow developers to focus on what needs to be done rather than how to do it, they can often produce results more quickly and efficiently.
Enhanced Readability: The focus on outcomes makes non-procedural code easier to read and understand, even for those unfamiliar with the original code 
2
.
Easier Maintenance: Non-procedural languages often lead to less complex code, which reduces the likelihood of bugs and makes maintenance simpler 
2
.


3 Sources
Conclusion
Non-procedural languages represent a significant departure from traditional procedural programming paradigms. By focusing on the end goal rather than the means of achieving it, these languages enable developers to write more abstract, efficient, and maintainable code. They are particularly useful in scenarios where the requirements can be clearly defined without needing to delve into implementation details.
These features make non-procedural languages an excellent choice for specific applications, particularly in database management, artificial intelligence, and high-level data manipulation tasks.

[flocard_faq.json] Python is a high-level, general-purpose programming language known for its readability and simplicity. It was created by Guido van Rossum and first released in 1991. Python supports multiple programming paradigms, including procedural, object-oriented, and functional programming.

Key Features

Python is dynamically typed and garbage-collected, making it flexible and easy to use. It has a simple syntax that is similar to the English language, which allows developers to write programs with fewer lines of code compared to other programming languages. Python's design philosophy emphasizes code readability, using significant indentation to define code blocks.

Uses and Applications

Python is widely used in various fields due to its versatility and extensive libraries. Some common applications include:

Web Development: Python can be used to create web applications using frameworks like Django and Flask.

Data Science: Python is popular in data science for building AI models, data analysis, and machine learning using libraries like TensorFlow, Keras, and scikit-learn.

Automation: Python can automate tasks such as web scraping and data manipulation using libraries like BeautifulSoup and pandas.

Game Development: Python can be used to develop 2D and 3D games using libraries like Pygame.

CAD: Python can be used for computer-aided design (CAD) to create 2D and 3D models.

Advantages and Disadvantages

Advantages

Easy to Learn: Python's syntax is simple and easy to understand, making it a great choice for beginners

Declarative Approach: Non-procedural languages, also known as declarative languages, focus on defining the desired outcomes rather than the specific steps to reach those outcomes. This approach allows for more concise and expressive code 
2
.
Function Development: These languages enable the creation of complex functions from simpler, existing functions. This means that coding is often shorthand for specifying relationships, constraints, or operations 
2
.
Simplicity: The semantics of non-procedural languages tend to be simpler compared to procedural languages. This simplicity can lead to improved readability and easier maintenance of code 
2
.
Automatic Optimization: The underlying systems can often optimize execution automatically, which helps in achieving better performance without requiring manual optimization by the developer 
1
.


4 Sources
Examples of Non-Procedural Languages
SQL (Structured Query Language): Used for managing and querying relational databases, SQL allows users to request data without needing to specify the exact retrieval method.
LISP: A language primarily used in artificial intelligence, known for its symbolic expression capabilities and functional programming features.
PROLOG: A logic programming language that emphasizes the use of rules and facts to perform logical inference 
2
.


2 Sources
Advantages of Non-Procedural Languages
Higher Productivity: Since these languages allow developers to focus on what needs to be done rather than how to do it, they can often produce results more quickly and efficiently.
Enhanced Readability: The focus on outcomes makes non-procedural code easier to read and understand, even for those unfamiliar with the original code 
2
.
Easier Maintenance: Non-procedural languages often lead to less complex code, which reduces the likelihood of bugs and makes maintenance simpler 
2
.


3 Sources
Conclusion
Non-procedural languages represent a significant departure from traditional procedural programming paradigms. By focusing on the end goal rather than the means of achieving it, these languages enable developers to write more abstract, efficient, and maintainable code. They are particularly useful in scenarios where the requirements can be clearly defined without needing to delve into implementation details.
These features make non-procedural languages an excellent choice for specific applications, particularly in database management, artificial intelligence, and high-level data manipulation tasks.

[Week1.2.docx] Week1 1.2 Cover cosine similarity, dense vs sparse retrieval Cosine similarity is a way to find out how similar two things are when we are comparing texts or data. Cosine similarity it only looks at their direction and tells us how much two things are pointing in the same direction, irrespective of there distance from each other. In simple words, it is similar to asking, “Do these two people have the same idea, even if they say it differently?” It’s widely used in AI, machine learning, text analysis, and recommendation systems, especially when comparing two texts or items. How is It Used? Search engines: Find documents similar to your query Recommendation systems: Recommend similar movies, books, or products Chatbots: Understand if user messages are similar to known questions Basic Understanding Example: Let’s say we have two sentences: A: “I love ice cream.” B: “I enjoy ice cream.” These are different sentences, but they mean almost the same thing. Cosine similarity helps the computer understand that these two are very close in meaning almost like how your brain naturally understands it. Cosine similarity turns angle into a score between -1 and 1, If the Output: +1 → Vectors are p

How is It Used? Search engines: Find documents similar to your query Recommendation systems: Recommend similar movies, books, or products Chatbots: Understand if user messages are similar to known questions Basic Understanding Example: Let’s say we have two sentences: A: “I love ice cream.” B: “I enjoy ice cream.” These are different sentences, but they mean almost the same thing. ointing in the same direction means very similar 0 → Vectors are perpendicular and has no similarity. -1 → Vectors are pointing in opposite direction and are completely dissimilar. If Cosine similarity turns angle into a score between -1 and 1, If the Output: +1 → Vectors are pointing in the same direction means very similar 0 → Vectors are perpendicular and has no similarity. -1 → Vectors are pointing in opposite direction and are completely dissimilar. Cosine Similarity Formula: cos(Θ)= A.B ÷||A||×||B|| Let us know, how it works; Here A.B is the dot product (it is a way to combine them into a single number of two vectors are combined into a single number). Example, consider these vectors; Vector A= [a1, a2, an] and Vector B= [b1, b2, bn] then; A. B= a1*b1+ a2*b2+…+ an*bn ||A|| and ||B|| are the length (Euclidean norm) of a vector from the distance of origin to the point represented by the vector. Example, if a vector A = [a1, a2, a3, …an] then: ||A|| = √a12+a22…+an2 Example, let us say; A = [3,2,0,5] Then the magnitude is: ||A|| = √32+22+02+52 √38 = 6.16(Approx) This value tells us the "length" of the arrow from the origin [0, 0, 0, 0] to [3, 2, 0, 5]. Real-Life Example of Cosine
